maps.name: Recording - Jul 09, 02:42 PM
maps.comment:
Challenging grade and a long section of wind gusts and slippery scree to the summit, but worth it for the panoramic views at the top and for about 2,000 ft above treeline. Probably the best hike in Banff until more snow melts.

On-trail before 7am and back down before 3pm. Passed a couple dozen hikers but it wasn't too crowded even on the weekend.

When you get to the scree, STAY LEFT! It is much looser on the (climber's) right side, and what looks like a trail there is more like a ski track than a hike. Acceptable on the way down if you have poles, but a recipe for treadmilling on the way up. The Alltrails track is better than the route marked on the trail map.

No snow, so no spikes needed, but you will want good tread and probably trekking poles.

maps.name: Mt Hale - Aug 15
maps.comment: No view but still a nice summit. A great one for downhill running - we descended in about 40 minutes.

maps.name: Recording - Aug 01, 03:05 PM
maps.comment:
Great condition, with just a few blown-down trees on trail and surprisingly little flooding for how wet it's been.

A bit of poison ivy on Passaconaway but not bad. I do recommend the spur trail from Passaconaway to the northward overlook if you've got the time - Carrigain Notch looks cool.

Do the loop clockwise (Whiteface first) so you can jog the "green tunnel" on the way back down.

Difficulty was normal for the Whites. Great weather and a great hike.

maps.name: Recording - Nov 21, 04:38 PM
maps.description:
Great weather today! Logging road was pretty boring, but the views at the top were nice. Panoramic views of Moosilauke and Monadnock.

10 miles roundtrip from the school parking lot.
